Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms Program in the Chemistry Division at the National Science Foundation supports Professor Charles L. Perrin of the University of California, San Diego, who will perform research to elucidate the relation between molecular structure and chemical reactivity. The research covers a wide range of topics, including symmetry of hydrogen bonds; isotope effects, conformational effects, the reactivity of a p-benzyne diradical toward nucleophiles, and the reactivity of malonic anhydrides. The success of these studies will rely on powerful and informative nuclear magnetic resonance methods.

This is all curiosity-driven basic research. The projects are excellent for training students to formulate and test hypotheses, to ask and answer questions, to solve problems, to use modern instrumentation, to analyze data, and to exercise critical thinking. The eventual utility of these studies remains long-range, inasmuch as they are not aimed at practical application but at developing a thorough understanding that will guide further research. Professor Perrin has been appointed as Chair of an international task force charged with revising the online IUPAC Glossary of Terms Used in Physical Organic Chemistry, which provides a major service to students and researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The general goal of this project has been an investigation of how molecular structure determines chemical reactivity. Throughout I have approached fundamental questions of structure, reactivity, and kinetics with a critical sense and with a thorough knowledge of chemistry. Among the most noteworthy results from this grant period are (a) defining the scope of a new reaction that we had discovered (nucleophilic addition to a diradical, in contrast to its usual radical reactivity); (b) the demonstration that the resulting "naked" aryl anion is so reactive as to be very unselective, which distinguishes it from aryllithiums and aryl Grignards, which have long been stand-ins for the aryl anion; (c) the evidence that hydrogen-bonded species that are symmetric in crystals are a mixture of tautomers in solution and that the difference is due to solvation and the formation of "solvatomers" (isomers that differ in solvation); (d) measurement of the solvent kinetic isotope effect in an aldol condensation, permitting at last the elucidation of its complete mechanism; (e) the counterintuitive result that a secondary isotope effect can be larger than the corresponding primary one; (f) what I hope is the final rejection of an inductive effect as responsible for secondary equilibrium isotope effects on acidity, and acceptance of n-σ* delocalization; (g) kinetics of the unusually rapid decomposition of malonic anhydrides (substances that had been sought for 70 years before we succeeded in preparing them); (h) an invited chapter for Methods in Enzymology describing in detail the NMR titration method that we had developed for highly accurate measurement of relative acidities; and (i) collaborative efforts with colleagues at UCSD and UCBerkeley, all of which happened because of my reputation for expertise in kinetics.

I think that the outcomes of this research are remarkable for their breadth and for their capacity to provide definitive results that are sometimes surprising. This is all fundamental research, of high intellectual merit, and with no immediate application except for the pursuit of new knowledge and a deep understanding of chemistry. I think that the outcomes of this research are remarkable for their breadth and for their capacity to provide definitive results that are sometimes surprising. It may be noted that in 2015 my research was recognized with the James Flack Norris Award in Physical Organic Chemistry, presented by the American Chemical Society.

This research has provided students with an excellent opportunity to develop problem-solving skills while working on fundamental aspects of molecular structure and reactivity. Most of my students have chosen to enter academia, usually at small teaching institutions, but there have been other career choices. My four most recent thesis students are (1) in formulations research at J&J; (2) a postdoc at Aarhus University while searching for a professorship  in the US, (3) the manager of introductory laboratories at the University of Delaware, and a researcher at BioBlocks, a small medicinal chemistry lab in San Diego. Moreover, I am proud of the inclusion of several students from underrepresented groups, including women and Hispanics. Also, I have taken advantage of our proximity to Mexico to participate in congresses of the Mexican Chemical Society.

Moreover, this research displays a nice interplay with teaching. One publication arose from my responsibilities as a manuscript reviewer and another from a conference presentation. Now they are intended to guide researchers worldwide. Another arose from the advanced course that I give on Kinetics and Mechanism. For a question on the 2010 Final Exam I incorporated some misstatements from a leading textbook of advanced organic chemistry and then developed the correction into a research project. Also, my role as Chair of the Task Force for Revision of the IUPAC Glossary of Physical-Organic Chemistry shows how I combine research and teaching with the education of chemists worldwide.
